The Richland School Board is pleased to announce that Dr. Shelley Redinger, a veteran educator with deep roots in the Richland School District community, will be the district’s next superintendent.

The Board hired Dr. Redinger, who has spent the past eight years as superintendent of Spokane Public Schools and has served in that role in two other districts, during its June 23 board meeting. Board members say they are excited to have an educator of Dr. Redinger’s caliber taking the helm of the district beginning Aug. 1.

“Shelley checks all the boxes of what our community told us they wanted in the next superintendent,” says Board President Rick Jansons. “We found her to be warm and a good listener, with a track record of success in the districts she previously led. She is an innovative leader, who builds trust through authenticity, sincerity and humility. She has demonstrated the ability to collaboratively implement change for continuous improvement.”

Learn more about Dr. Redinger and join us in welcoming her!: https://bit.ly/3hWr4gQ

Way to go, Adelyn! #RSDawesome

And more students like Cristofer are taking and excelling in AP courses in our schools. The College Board, the organization that oversees the AP program, placed RSD on its 10th annual AP District Honor Roll in recognition for expanding access to the program while maintaining or growing student success. Ellie Rosser’s first job out of college was working in a special education program at Sacajawea Elementary. Now she’s back at the school as a site coordinator for Communities In Schools and couldn’t be happier.

“There’s just something about working in a school where the kids are always so happy to see you,” Ellie says.

Her role at the school is wide-ranging; she was making home visits in August to touch base with prospective kindergarten families before she’d even had a chance to set up her office. She’s currently supporting literacy and attendance initiatives at Sacajawea and while planning a morning breakfast club for students to help them feel more connected to school. She’s also there to be a resource for families, connect them to services and be supportive.

“I love this work because I love helping people,” Ellie says. “There’s something about sitting down with someone in a tough situation, being able to listen to them and offer solutions.” #RSDawesome

The Richland High School marching band recently competed at the Tumwater Marching Band Festival but it was off the field where the students, their band director and their bus driver made the biggest impression.

The band’s staging area was next to where all the other bands would pass on their way to perform. As each band passed by, the Richland High band members always made sure to cheer and encourage them, impressing Richland School Board President Rick Jansons and other spectators.

Then, when band director Jason Rose learned that the bus of another high school band scheduled to compete broke down 15 miles away, he approached RSD bus driver Ron McCauley about helping them out. Mr. McCauley was able to get to the students in need, help them transfer their equipment to his bus and get them to the festival in time that they were able to compete.

Job well done, RHS marching band students, Mr. Rose and Mr. McCauley. You showed you are truly #RSDawesome.

Washington State Arts Commission
September 30, 2019 at 8:53 AM ·

September 15 to October 15 is Hispanic Heritage Month. These Latinx artists and their artworks are a part of the fabric of our state’s vibrant communities and cultural identity. They reflect our diverse heritage and perspectives—past, present, and future. Click to explore the web exhibition at https://bit.ly/2lXHVr4.

Seen here: “Dragonfly on Leaf” by Mauricio Robalino , located at Jason Lee Elementary, Richland School District , Richland, Washington.

Every student who Ree Rykiel helps on the bus each day is different and she says it takes a team to meet their needs.

A former health room aide, Ree has been a bus attendant for 16 years. Her job ranges from helping students get on and off the bus safely to being there for them during the ride.

Ree says she’s able to support students because she works with a bus driver and others who share the same level of dedication.

“What keeps me coming back is the camaraderie,” she says. “We’re good at our jobs and we like what we do.” #RSDawesome
